In the UK higher education is not compulsory in any absolute sense. However, it is effectively a largely non-negotiable prerequisite for entry to many fields of employment. Those conditions are largely set by employers, industries and professions, not the state. So, higher education is not compulsory, but depending on a student’s aspirations may effectively be so. For example, I was a journalist for more than 20 years. I have a degree, but it was not a condition of employment when I applied for the first reporting job I was offered after university. Employers looking for entry-level journalists in the UK today for the most part specify a degree as a criteria an applicant must achieve to be considered for a job. So, higher education is both compulsory and not compulsory, depending on what one wants to do with one’s life. I imagine that in effect employers today are prepared to waive their degree requirement in the case of otherwise suitable candidates. But in reality it is hard to get noticed by them without a degree, as one could say it’s part of the “triage” process employers use to whittle down long lists of applicants. I think higher education should not be “compulsory” in any sense, but in reality that’s hard to achieve when you’re an employer. (In the interests of full disclosure, I’m a university journalism lecturer).

Yes. School education should be provided to all. However that should not be the case of higher education. Assimilating higher education requires aptitude and effort on the part of students. If they don’t have the aptitude and are not putting in adequate effort, what is `supplied’ would be wasted. (On the other hands, there are social benefits if all children are in schools even if some of them don’t learn much). However higher education should be provided to all students who have the interest and aptitude irrespective of their ability to pay. A situation where only a minority can afford higher education due to the cost is not desirable.

Higher education (i.e., college) is not compulsory in the U.S. Only about 40–50% of people in the U.S. attend college, and only about 30% complete the degree. If college were compulsory, it would (a) bankrupt a lot of families trying to afford it or drown them in student loans, and (b) it would diminish the educational atmosphere, as you’ have swarms of students forced to attend who did not want to.
